summary:
<think>
Okay, I need to summarize this document about Otto Frenzel in 3-5 sentences. Let me start by reading through the content carefully.

The main points seem to be his career in banking and his brief ownership of the Pittsburgh Penguins. He was a banking executive from 1956 to 1995, with roles at Merchants National Bank and later National City Bank. He was part of a family that had multiple generations in leadership roles there. Then, he co-owned the Penguins from 1975-1977, bought the team when it was bankrupt, made some financial decisions like dissolving the farm system, and then sold it. He died in 2010 at 80.

I should make sure to mention his banking career, the family aspect, the Penguins ownership, the key actions during that time, and his death. Need to keep it concise, avoiding minor details. Check for key concepts: banking roles, ownership of Penguins, financial decisions, sale of the team, and death. Avoid citations and focus on main topics. Let me structure that into 3-5 sentences.
</think>

Otto N. "Nick" Frenzel III was a prominent banking executive who served as chairman of Merchants National Bank and National City Bank of Indiana from the 1970s until his retirement in 1995, continuing a family legacy of leadership in the institution. He briefly co-owned the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins from 1975 to 1977, purchasing the financially struggling team for $3.8 million and implementing cost-cutting measures like dissolving its farm system, though he eventually sold his stake to Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. Frenzel's career spanned over four decades in banking, marked by familial ties and strategic leadership, before his death in 2010 at age 80.

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Otto Frenzel


# Otto Frenzel



**Otto N. [S2] "Nick" Frenzel III** was a former banking executive from 1956 until 1995. [S3] He was also a co-owner, secretary, and treasurer of the Pittsburgh Penguins from 1975 until 1977. [S4] ## Career


### Banking

He was a 1954 graduate of the Wharton School of Business, University of Pennsylvania and served two years in the United States Air Force. [S5] Frenzel obtained the rank of 1st Lieutenant (O-2) before his release in 1956. [S6] He started his career in banking at Merchants National Bank and Trust Company in Indianapolis, Indiana in 1956 and was elected to the board in 1964. [S7] He later became president of the company in 1970 and chairman of the board in 1972. [S8] Otto was the sixth member of his family to serve as the Merchant's chief executive. [S9] He was elected chairman of the Merchants National Corporation (parent company of Merchants National Bank) in 1979 and was also elected chairman of the board of National City Bank of Indiana in 1992, serving in the role until his retirement in 1995. [S10] ### Franchise owner

Frenzel, along with Wren Blair and Al Savill, was briefly co-owner, secretary, and treasurer of the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins. [S11] The group had purchased the bankrupt team from the league for $3.8 million. [S12] Upon becoming owner of the Penguins, he dissolved the farm system to save money and was forced to trade draft picks to keep the team marginally competitive. [S13] Savill and Frenzel remained co-owners of the team for two seasons, eventually selling the team was sold to local shopping mall developer Edward J. [S14] DeBartolo Sr. [S15] in February 1977. [S16] ## Death

Frenzel died on December 24, 2010. [S17] He was 80 years old.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ

qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Otto Frenzel's full name was Otto N. "Nick" Frenzel III.<cite>[S2]</cite></statement>
qa_pairs.thinking:
Okay, let's see. The question is asking for Otto Frenzel's full name. The supporting context provided has several sentences. Let me go through them one by one.

Looking at the first sentence [S1], it just says "Otto Frenzel". That's probably his first and last name, but maybe there's more. Then in [S2], it mentions "Otto N. [S2] "Nick" Frenzel III". Wait, that seems like his full name. So his full name would be Otto N. "Nick" Frenzel III. The [S2] is a citation here. But I need to check if there are other mentions. 

Other sentences talk about his career, but not his full name. The rest of the context mentions his roles and dates, but not his full name again. So the answer should be Otto N. "Nick" Frenzel III, cited from [S2]. The first sentence [S1] only has his first and last name, but [S2] provides the full name with the middle initial and nickname. So the correct answer is in [S2].

qa_pairs.chunk:
[S1] Otto Frenzel


# Otto Frenzel



**Otto N. [S2] "Nick" Frenzel III** was a former banking executive from 1956 until 1995. [S3] He was also a co-owner, secretary, and treasurer of the Pittsburgh Penguins from 1975 until 1977. [S4] ## Career


### Banking

He was a 1954 graduate of the Wharton School of Business, University of Pennsylvania and served two years in the United States Air Force. [S5] Frenzel obtained the rank of 1st Lieutenant (O-2) before his release in 1956. [S6] He started his career in banking at Merchants National Bank and Trust Company in Indianapolis, Indiana in 1956 and was elected to the board in 1964. [S7] He later became president of the company in 1970 and chairman of the board in 1972. [S8] Otto was the sixth member of his family to serve as the Merchant's chief executive. [S9] He was elected chairman of the Merchants National Corporation (parent company of Merchants National Bank) in 1979 and was also elected chairman of the board of National City Bank of Indiana in 1992, serving in the role until his retirement in 1995. [S10] ### Franchise owner

Frenzel, along with Wren Blair and Al Savill, was briefly co-owner, secretary, and treasurer of the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins. [S11] The group had purchased the bankrupt team from the league for $3.8 million. [S12] Upon becoming owner of the Penguins, he dissolved the farm system to save money and was forced to trade draft picks to keep the team marginally competitive. [S13] Savill and Frenzel remained co-owners of the team for two seasons, eventually selling the team was sold to local shopping mall developer Edward J. [S14] DeBartolo Sr. [S15] in February 1977. [S16] ## Death

Frenzel died on December 24, 2010. [S17] He was 80 years old.ᶜⁱᵗᵃᵗⁱᵒⁿ ⁿᵉᵉᵈᵉᵈ
qa_pairs.question: Who were Otto Frenzel's co-owners when he purchased the Penguins?
qa_pairs.answer: <statement>Otto Frenzel's co-owners when he purchased the Penguins were Wren Blair and Al Savill.<cite>[S11]</cite></statement>

In the section about the franchise owner, there's a sentence that says: "Frenzel, along with Wren Blair and Al Savill, was briefly co-owner, secretary, and treasurer of the NHL's Pittsburgh Penguins." That seems relevant. So the co-owners mentioned here are Wren Blair and Al Savill. 

Another part mentions that Savill and Frenzel remained co-owners for two seasons before selling the team. But the question is specifically about when he purchased the Penguins, so the initial co-owners would be Wren Blair and Al Savill. 

I should check if there are any other names mentioned. The passage also mentions Edward J. DeBartolo Sr. as the one who bought the team in 1977, but that's after they sold it. So the co-owners during the purchase would be the ones listed in sentence S11. 

So the answer should be Wren Blair and Al Savill, cited from S11.
